Name: Linear Programming
Description: Optimizing a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints. Variables are continuous.
column8: Resource allocation, production planning, diet problem

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: An extension of LP where some or all decision variables are restricted to be integers. Combines continuous and discrete variables.
Example: but modern solvers are very effective for many practical problems.
Appearances: Facility location, supply chain design, vehicle routing

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: An optimization problem where the objective function or some of the constraints are nonlinear.
Solvability: Solvability varies greatly. Convex NLPs are generally easier to solve for a global optimum. Non-convex NLPs are very difficult.
Example: Portfolio optimization with transaction costs, chemical process engineering

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: A broad class of problems that involves minimizing a convex function over a convex set. Includes LP and some QPs as special cases.
Solvability: Highly solvable. If a local optimum is found
Example: it is guaranteed to be the global optimum.
Appearances: Support Vector Machines (SVM), geometric problems, parameter estimation

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: Optimizing a quadratic objective function subject to linear constraints. Variables are continuous.
Solvability: Efficiently solvable if the objective function is convex; otherwise

Name: Integer Programming
Description: A type of optimization problem where all decision variables are restricted to be integers.
Solvability: NP-hard. More general and often harder than MILP if the structure is not linear.

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: A field concerned with finding an optimal object from a finite set of objects. Often involves graphs and discrete structures.
Solvability: Many problems are NP-hard. Requires specialized algorithms (e.g.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler, overlapping subproblems and solving each subproblem only once.
Solvability: Solvability depends on the state space and problem structure. Can be very efficient if applicable.
Example: Shortest path problems, inventory control, sequence alignment

Name: Stochastic Programming
Description: A framework for modeling optimization problems that involve uncertainty. Data is often represented by probability distributions.
Example: often requiring specialized decomposition methods or approximation schemes.
Appearances: Capacity planning under demand uncertainty, financial planning

Name: Multi-objective Optimization
Description: Problems involving more than one objective function to be optimized simultaneously, resulting in a set of trade-off (Pareto optimal) solutions.
Solvability: Does not yield a single optimal solution but a set of them. Solvers aim to find or approximate the Pareto front.
Example: Product design (cost vs. quality), environmental policy (economy vs. pollution)
